College of Vehicles and Energy Yanshan University Qinhuangdao 066000 China Graphical abstract The structure dependency of dehydrogenation activity and stability among Pd-based phosphide NPs was illustrated by comparative study of Pd3P and PdP2 surfaces. A large number of alloy nanoparticle catalysts with novel configurations and compositions have been reported for efficient propane dehydrogenation. Although efforts have been made to rejuvenate the spent catalysts, the recovery of these well-defined active sites is still a daunting challenge. In this work, silica supported palladium-phosphide nanoparticles, with uniform particle sizes (∼2.5 nm) and specific crystal structures were prepared and systematically characterized. The combined structure analysis reveals that the exposed Pd site changes from metal Pd surface to few-atom Pd ensembles and fully isolated Pd atoms with gradually increasing P content. For identical reaction conditions of propane dehydrogenation, both the clustered Pd atoms and isolated Pdδ+ atoms exhibited dehydrogenation rates that is >10 times higher than the corresponding rate over Pd nanoparticle. Kinetic measurements demonstrated that the clustered Pd atoms on the surface of Pd3P nanoparticle shows the highest activity for C–H activation, while its also favored by coke deposition, leading to a trade-off relationship between activity and stability. By contrast, the Pd atoms on PdP2 surface exhibited a compromised dehydrogenation performance. Based on the deactivation mechanism of Pd-phosphide catalyst during dehydrogenation/regeneration cycles, an effective regeneration method, washing catalyst bed with alkaline-ethanol under mild conditions, was developed to remove deposited coke around dehydrogenation sites without sintering of nanoparticles. The structure–activity/stability relationship insights and facile regeneration method for the binary catalysts in this work offer improved knowledge of propane dehydrogenation catalyst. Keywords Phosphide catalyst Propane dehydrogenation Coordination structure Regeneration Coke elimination Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Propylene is one of the most widely demanded platform chemicals, with a myriad of uses in the chemical industry. Traditionally, propylene is produced through steam cracking or fluid catalytic cracking of oil feedstock, as well as via coal-based routes using methanol as an intermediate [1,2]. However, both methods involve significant energy consumption and generate substantial carbon dioxide emissions [3]. With the growing availability of propane derived from shale gas, the direct dehydrogenation of propane (PDH) has gained attention as an on-purpose method for propylene production. Furthermore, in the case of propane dehydrogenation, only H2 is generated as a by-product, showing potential for H2 supply [4]. Chromium- and platinum-based catalysts have been applied in commercial PDH processes [5], but both suffer from rapid deactivation caused by coke deposition and catalyst-structure deterioration during reaction/regeneration cycles [6,7]. The development of alternative PDH catalysts, thus, represents an intense field of research. Further enhancements of the performance of metallic Pt catalysts have been achieved through nanoscale alloying with non-catalytic metal additives, typically Sn [8–12], Zn [13–15], Cu [16], Ga [17,18], or even rare-earth metals [19]. Previous theoretical and experimental studies have demonstrated that diluting the adjacent Pt atoms by alloying with Sn shut down C–C bond cleavage while minimizing the loss of the active sites responsible for dehydrogenation [20–23]. In addition to metallic Pt, other metallic catalysts, such as Rh and Ir alloy nanoparticle [24–28], have recently been reported to exhibit superior dehydrogenation performance. Moreover, the systematic studies on structure-performance relationship on these alloy catalysts in PDH have indicated that the ability of promoter metals to suppress side reactions is seemingly independent of the active metal’s intrinsic ability to activate C–H and C–C bonds [29,30], which definitely open up a larger space of catalyst compositions and structures for the development of robust PDH catalysts. Recently, a few reports have shown that alloys of Pd can have dehydrogenation selectivities comparable to Pt alloys, although metal Pd is less selective than metal Pt. For both Pt- and other alloy catalysts, however, coke deposition cannot be totally avoided with time on stream, which requires the periodic coke elimination to achieve sustainable operation. Consequently, the sintering of metal nanoparticles (NPs) and phase separation of binary alloys are usually accompanied by an oxidative atmosphere with high temperature. Commercial Pt–Sn catalyst, for example, necessitate a corrosive process called oxychlorination to recover the well-dispersed alloy particles [31,32]. Other regeneration strategies have been developed to reverse the sintering and restore the active sites, such as treatment of spent catalysts in flowing H2 or O2/H2O steam at elevated temperature [33,34]. It has been observed that the catalytic activity was not fully restored after coke elimination followed by hydrogen reduction due to inadequate recovery of metal sintering and atomic configuration of metal site. Phosphorus (P) can serve as a structural promoter, and metal phosphides (MxPy) are typically considered P-doped metal “alloys” [35]. Furthermore, the characteristics of size and electronic structure of P atoms, compared to metal atoms, offer additional binding possibilities for enhanced performance. Earlier studies on metal phosphide catalysts for PDH, including P modified Fe [36], Ru [37], and Pt nanoparticles [38], have demonstrated that P atoms act not only as a spacer creating atomically isolated metal atom sites, but also the bond formation between d-metal and p-block elements alters the energy of the metal valence orbitals, promoting the desorption of desired propylene and further enhancing its selectivity. Typically, metal phosphides with an excellent resistance to sulfur poisoning making them more robust for practical PDH process [39,40]. Using in situ synchrotron X-ray absorption spectroscopy and resonant inelastic X-ray scattering spectroscopy, we found that P bonded Pt2+ sites in crystalline PtP2 nanoparticles are quite stable, without metallic Pt or PtO species were detected after treatment in H2 or O2 atmosphere at 550 ℃ [38]. The unique chemical properties of metal phosphides, compared to metallic alloys, inspire the development of efficient regeneration methods for phosphide catalysts. The objective of this study was to identify the dehydrogenation and deactivation characteristics of active sites on Pd-phosphide nanoparticles with varied atomic configurations of Pd atoms. Firstly, P-modified Pd nanoparticles supported on SiO2 support with varying P/Pd molar ratios were synthesized, and their compositions and structures were elucidated by an array of advanced characterization techniques, including in situ X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), in situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS), and in situ diffuse reflective infrared Fourier-transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) of CO adsorption, etc. Rate measurements and product distribution analysis were then performed to assess the activation capability of C–H and C–C bonds on the coordination structures of the Pd atom. Significantly, a facile approach for the rejuvenation of Pd-phosphide catalysts was developed based on its deactivation mechanism. Overall, this work reveals the characteristics of dehydrogenation chemistry over Pd-phosphide catalysts, and demonstrates a promising strategy for the rejuvenation of phosphide catalysts for long-term reaction/regeneration cycles. 2 Experimental methods 2.1 Catalyst synthesis SiO2 (Davisil Grade 646 silica gel, Sigma-Aldrich, 35–60 mesh, pore volume 1.2 cm3/g) supported NPs with 2.0 wt% Pd loading were synthesized by sequential incipient wetness impregnation, and the obtained catalysts were denoted as Pd–P/SiO2-X (X = 0.5, 1, 2, 5, 10) according to their targeted P/Pd atomic ratios. Phosphorus was firstly loaded using phosphoric acid as a precursor. Taking Pd–P/SiO2-1 as an example, 77 mg H3PO3 (99 wt%) was dissolved in deionized water to give a total amount of 6.0 mL, and dropwise added to 5.0 g of dry SiO2 with hand stirring. The obtained sample was calcined at 500 °C for 4 h after removing water in a 125 ℃ oven overnight. Then, 6 mL of 0.19 mol/L palladium solution (Pd(NH3)4(NO3)2, Sigma-Aldrich, 99.9 wt%), pH-fixed by adding NH4OH to 11, was dropwise added to the P/SiO2 with hand stirring. The obtained sample was dried overnight at 125 ℃, followed by calcination at 550 ℃ for another 0.5 h. The other Pd–P/SiO2 catalysts were prepared by the same procedure except for the different amounts of H3PO4. For comparison, the monometallic Pd/SiO2 sample was also prepared by the pH-fixed impregnation method and the same reduction process. 2.2 Characterizations The actual loadings of Pd and P on fresh and spent catalysts were determined by Agilent 7700 inductively coupled plasma-mass spectrometry (ICP-MS). The experiments of temperature-programmed hydrogen reduction (H2-TPR) were performed in a chemical adsorption apparatus (Autochem Ⅱ 2920, Micrometrics), coupled with a mass spectrometer to collect PH3 (m/z = 34) and H2O (m/z = 18) signals. The tests of C3H8 temperature-programmed surface reaction (C3H8-TPSR) were performed on the same apparatus. 50 mg of catalyst was treated at 500 ℃ in a stream of 10 vol% H2/Ar (30 mL/min) and then cooled down to 50 ℃, and then exposed to a 20 vol% C3H8/N2 at a heating rate of 5 ℃/min. The output products, including C3H8, C3H6, and CH4 (m/e equals 29, 41, and 16, respectively), were detected via mass spectrometer instantaneously. The size and phase structures of the nanoparticles were studied by Talos-F200X G2 at an acceleration voltage of 200 eV, which was equipped with a Super-X energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectrometer, STEM annular detectors and a Gatan Enfinium ER (model 977) spectrometer with a DUAL electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) option. The palladium dispersion of the phosphide catalyst was measured using H2 chemisorption, carried out on a Micrometric ChemiSorb 2920 at 50 ℃. By contrast, the metal dispersion of Pd/SiO2 was calculated based on the average size (d) of Pd NPs, since the formation of PdHx species using H2 chemisorption resulted in an overestimated Pd dispersion. XPS spectra were obtained using a Kratos Axis Ultra DLD spectrometer and charge neutralizer with Al Kα. Before collecting data, the samples were treated under H2/N2 flow at 550 ℃ in an attached chamber and transferred in a vacuum to avoid oxidation by air. In situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier-transform spectra (DRIFTS) were collected on a Nicolet iS50 spectrometer with a mercury cadmium telluride detector cooled by liquid nitrogen. Prior to the test, ∼20 mg of the sample was reduced at 550 ℃ under 5 vol% H2/N2 for 30 min, and the background spectrum was collected after purging with N2 at room temperature for 40 min. Then, the pre-reduced samples were exposed to 10 vol% CO in N2 at 25 ℃ for 40 min, and the sample IR spectra were collected after purging with N2 for 30 min. X-ray absorption spectroscopy measurements at the Pd K (24350 eV) edge were conducted in transmission mode on the 10-BM at the Advanced Photon Source (APS), Argonne National Laboratory. A Pd foil spectrum was acquired simultaneously with each measurement for energy calibration. Samples were ground into fine powder and pressed into a cylindrical sample holder. Before collecting the spectra, the samples were reduced at 550 ℃ with 5 vol% H2/He (50 mL/min), and then cooled to room temperature in He (100 mL/min). Thermogravimetric analysis of deposited coke on the spent catalysts was carried out on a Bruker TH-DSC instrument under 10 vol% O2/Ar flow (20 mL/min) and the temperature ramp rate was 10 ℃/min. 2.3 Dehydrogenation test and catalyst regeneration The tests of propane dehydrogenation were carried out at atmospheric pressure using a fixed-bed quartz micro-reactor (6 mm inner diameter). The sieved sample was diluted with silica sand (40–60 mesh particle size) to 0.3 g and packed in the center of the reactor. A K-type thermocouple was placed directly above the catalyst bed inside the quartz tube to ensure accurate temperature measurement. Prior to the reactivity measurements, samples were heated to 550 ℃ under flowing 5 vol% H2/Ar (50 mL/min) and held at this temperature for 1 h. After pretreatments, C3H8 (99.9 %) was supplied to the catalyst bed. The flow rate of gases was controlled by means of mass flow controllers (Brooks), which were pre-calibrated by a bubble flow meter. Kinetics measurements were conducted over the range of 460–580 ℃. In all cases, conversion stayed far from the thermodynamic limit by increasing space velocity, which is defined as molC3H8·gcat −1·s−1. To compare the activity of Pd- and Pd-phosphide catalysts, the dehydrogenation rate (r) was measured and expressed as the mole of produced propylene per mole of active atoms per second (mols·molPd −1·s−1). The number of active atoms on the surface of the nanoparticle was determined by H2-chemisortion. On-line analysis of the reaction products was carried out using a gas chromatography (Agilent 8890A) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and HP-PLOT-Q column. The carbon balance over these phosphide catalysts was evaluated by comparing the number of moles of carbon in the outlet stream to the number of moles of carbon in the feed, and the calculated carbon balance was about 98 ± 3 % under the typical evaluating conditions. The propane conversion (X) and product selectivity (S) were calculated according to the following equations (1) X % = F in C 3 H 8 - F out C 3 H 8 F in C 3 H 8 × 100 % (2) S ( % ) = n i × F out ( i ) Σ i [ n i × F out ( i ) ] × 100 % (3) k d = l n ( 100 - C o n v t C o n v t ) - l n ( 100 - C o n v 0 C o n v 0 ) t where i represented the hydrocarbon product in the effluent gas, including CH4, C2H4, C2H6, and C3H6, n i was the number of carbon atoms of component i, and Fin (i) and Fout (i) were the corresponding flow rates for inlet and outlet gas i, respectively. In order to gain insights into the long-term stability of Pd-phosphide catalysts, we carried out four successive PDH runs (each 6 h long) interlaid with regeneration stages. The deactivation constant (k d) was calculated based on a simple empirical first-order deactivation model [41] to evaluate the catalyst stability in Eq. (3), where Conv 0 and Conv t represent the conversions measured at the initial and final stages of a PDH cycle, respectively, and t is time of stream. Means of regeneration, including ethanol washing followed by H2-treatment (W-H regeneration) and isothermal oxidative procedure followed by H2-treatment (O–H regeneration) are assessed. In the case of W-H regeneration, the reactor temperature was decreased below 100 ℃ in a stream of N2, and alkaline-ethanol (containing 0.01 M KOH) was pumped (with a feed-rate of 30 mL/h) and vaporized at 120 ℃ upstream of the reactor. The washing procedure was ceased when the effluent turned colorless. Then, the gases of 10 vol% H2/N2 were fed and heated to test temperature for 0.5 h for the next PDH run. For comparison, the sequential oxygen-hydrogen treatment (O–H regeneration) was also performed for the recovery of spent phosphide catalyst. Accordingly, 50 mL/min of dry synthetic air (20 vol% O2 balanced with N2) was passed in situ through the catalyst bed at 550 ℃ for 0.5 h. Then the air-feed was ceased, and 10 % H2/N2 was introduced at 550 ℃ for another 1 h. The gas flow was finally switched to 50 mL/min of flowing N2 for the next PDH run. After each reaction-regeneration run, the spent catalyst was retained for further characterization. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization of the Pd-phosphide catalyst P-modified Pd/SiO2 samples with varied P contents were prepared by the sequential impregnation method. Palladium loadings (1.88–1.97 wt%) of fresh catalysts were determined by ICP-MS, as detailed in Table S1. The lower P loadings were observed in all Pd–P/SiO2 samples, with values below the targeted levels. This discrepancy may be attributed to the loss of phosphine (PH3) during the reduction process. H2-TPR experiments were conducted to gain insight into the phosphidation processes occurring during the synthesis process. Fig. 1 shows the evolution of PH3 (m/z = 34) during the temperature-programmed reduction of the precursors. The different signal intensity and peak position indicate that the production of PH3 is significantly influenced by the atomic ratio of P/Pd. Specifically, the precursor of Pd–P/SiO2-1 exhibits minimal PH3 release at ∼360 ℃ during TPR process. Conversely, higher temperatures result in significantly enhanced production of PH3 when employing P/Pd ratios of 5 and 10. The formation of H2O in the TPR process was also monitored by mass spectrometry, shown in Fig. S1, in which an initial H2O peak at low temperature (<100 ℃) followed by a broad feature in the temperature range of 350–700 ℃ was observed. The H2O peak at low temperature is assigned to the reduction of ionic palladium species, while the higher temperature peaks are ascribed to the reduction of the phosphate precursor. The combination of the temperature at which H2O and PH3 are generated suggests that the reduction of phosphate compounds to form PH3 is catalyzed by the completely reduced Pd nanoparticles at low temperature (<100 ℃). These then react with the metallic Pd to form the Pd-phosphide particles. Moreover, studies of calcined precursors with different P/Pd ratios demonstrate a clear trend whereby the temperature for phosphidation increases with increasing P content. It should be noted that the phosphate is firstly generated after calcination, functioning as surface germination sites for the loading of palladium species, which generally promote the phosphidation and optimize the distribution of metal species during the H2-reduction process [42]. Through TEM characterization, the size of metal nanoparticle was examined, as shown in Fig. 2 and Fig. S2. In the case of the Pd–P/SiO2-1 sample (Fig. 2a-b and the corresponding inset), the dominant particles in the 2–3 nm range are observed to be well dispersed on silica, with a mean diameter of 2.5 nm and a standard deviation of 0.4 nm. With the exception of Pd–P/SiO2-1, highly dispersed NPs with an average size of ∼2.5 nm are prevalent in all Pd–P/SiO2 catalysts (Table S1). These are smaller than Pd NPs on the Pd/SiO2 catalyst (4.0 ± 1 nm), indicating a stronger interaction between P-modified Pd NPs and the silica support. Correspondingly, the metal dispersion of the Pd/SiO2 catalyst is estimated to be 28 %. The dispersion values of the Pd–P/SiO2 samples are found to be ∼35 % at low P/Pd ratios (0.5, 1, and 2), as described in Table S1, while the chemisorption of hydrogen sharply decreases with increasing P/Pd molar ratio to 10, possibly due to the coverage of NPs by excess phosphate [43]. The structure of Pd–P/SiO2-1 sample is further demonstrated by high-resolution TEM (Fig. 2b). The sample revealed well-resolved crystal nanoparticles with an interplanar spacing of 0.227 nm, which corresponded to the distance of the (031) crystal planes of the orthorhombic Pd3P [44]. Furthermore, the distributions and chemical states of P on the Pd–P/SiO2-5 sample are corroborated by STEM-EDX and STEM-EELS. The EDX element mappings in Fig. 2c reveal that the signal intensity of P in the region of the NPs is higher than that of on the SiO2, thereby suggesting the formation of Pd-phosphide NPs. Moreover, EEL spectra of the P K-edge were recorded from different regions indicated in Fig. 2c. As shown in Fig. 2d, a peak at 2150.2 eV is observed for the P K core edge on the nanoparticle, corresponding to 1 s → 3p dipole transition, which is lower than reported the P0 value (2150.5–2151.2) [45]. The proximity of the P K-edge onset to the P0 standard suggests that P is likely to be in weakly charged state in the phosphide NPs [46]. In contrast, a distinct positive shift (8.9 eV) is observed in the position of the bare SiO2 P K-edge peak (2159.6 eV), which is consistent with the presence of phosphate species [47]. The alteration in the electronic characteristics of Pd resulting from the formation of the Pd–P bond was then validated through in situ XPS experiments. The binding energies at 335.4 and 340.7 eV in the spectrum of Pd/SiO2 (Fig. 2e) were fitted to Pd 3d5/2 and Pd 3d3/2 respectively, demonstrating that the Pd atoms were in the metallic state [48]. Additionally, the Pd 3d 5/2 peak displayed a shift towards higher binding energy and a further scaled-up (from 0.1 to 0.8 eV) with an increase in P loading relative to a monometallic Pd reference. This finding corroborates prior reports that the formation of phosphide NPs causes an electron transfer from Pd to P, which results in a decrease in the local electron density on Pd, and an increase in electron binding energy [49]. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy was employed to investigate the configuration of surface Pd atoms in Pd–P/SiO2 catalysts. In the case of Pd/SiO2, the chemisorption of CO on Pd resulted in the emergence of two distinct infrared bands (Fig. 2f). The band centred at 2078 cm−1 was attributed to linearly bounded CO on the coordinatively unsaturated Pd atoms within Pd NPs, whereas the other band at 1960 cm−1 represented the bridged-mode of CO chemisorption on Pd NPs [50]. In contrast, the infrared signal associated with bridge-bonded CO decreased with increasing the P content, leaving only the sole linear adsorption mode on the Pd–P/SiO2-2 and Pd–P/SiO2-5. A plausible explanation was that the contiguous Pd atoms were blocked by the introduction of P through the formation of Pd–P bonds. It is noteworthy that the CO-adsorption bands on Pd–P/SiO2 catalysts exhibit a blue shift in comparison to the vertical line of these two bands on mono Pd catalyst. This shift corresponds to the generation of Pdδ+ atoms on the surface of the nanoparticle, which is consistent with the results obtained from EELS and XPS analysis. To gain insight into the short-range atomic structures of phosphide NPs, we conduct XAS measurements on the Pd–P/SiO2 samples. The Pd K-edge energy of Pd/SiO2 is 24350.6 eV (Table 1 ), which is identical to that of metallic Pd. For the case of Pd–P/SiO2 samples, the XANES energy shifts to a higher level (0.5 → 1.2 eV) with increasing P loadings (Fig. 3 a), suggesting a higher energy level of unfilled Pd 5s states [51], which agrees with XPS characterization results. In Fig. 3b, the Fourier transform k 2-weighted R-space EXAFS of Pd-containing samples shows a main peak at ∼2.5 Å that can be safely assigned to the Pd–Pd bond, being present in Pd metal foil. One additional peak below 2 Å in the Pd–P/SiO2 samples is at a higher R value if compared with the PdO peak [52], thus this peak can be inferred to the Pd–P bonds. Notably, the peak positions and Fourier transform magnitudes (shown in Fig. S3) continue to underdo alteration with the increase in P loading, which is indicative of scattering from P and changes in bond distance and coordination numbers. The rational values of the bond length and coordination number (CN) were obtained from k 2-weighted first shell fitting of the EXAFS spectra, utilizing scattering paths derived from crystal structures of the expected compounds, shown in Table 1. The Pd–Pd coordination number of Pd/SiO2 is estimated to be 10.2 at a distance of 2.72 Å. For Pd–P/SiO2-0.5, two overlapping peaks between 1.5 and 2 Å can be observed, indicating the coexistence of metal Pd and phosphide phases. The EXAFS spectrum of Pd–P/SiO2-0.5 was fit with FEFF6 simulated Pd–Pd (both in face-centered cubic Pd and Pd3P phase) and Pd–P scattering pairs. The coordination number of Pd–P is 1.5, and there are excessive Pd–Pd bonds corresponding to the FCC Pd phase, suggesting the formation of Pd-rich nanoparticles. As the P/Pd ratio is increased to 1, the Pd–P CN continues rise. Rational fits were obtained with a Pd–Pd bond length of 2.91 Å, with a CN of 6.2 and a Pd–P bond distance of 2.30 Å with a 1.6 CN. The Pd environment in Pd–P/SiO2-1 is well described by that of the Pd3P crystal (CNPd–Pd:CNPd–P = 4), which is consistent with the morphology observed by TEM. Further increasing P content leads to the formation of PdP2 phase, featuring longer Pd–P bonds, as listed in Table 1, and the decreased CN of Pd–Pd bond (4.7 for Pd–P/SiO2-2 and 3.1 for Pd–P/SiO2-5) indicates a greater number of neighboring P atoms around each Pd atom. The structural characterizations of Pd–P/SiO2 samples demonstrated that the activation of phosphorus during H2-reduction could lead to its incorporation into Pd NPs to form metal phosphide NPs. Furthermore, it was shown that the nanostructure and atomic configuration of Pd atoms on the surface of NPs could be manipulated via the adjustment of the amount of P. At low P loading, for example Pd–P/SiO2-0.5, EXAFS analysis indicated the formation of a Pd-rich core encased by a shell of Pd3P phase, and such phenomenon was also observed among the formation of RuP and PtP2 NPs [38,43]. With increasing P/Pd ratio, more P atoms migrated onto the Pd@Pd3P nanoparticles, leading to the formation of relatively pure Pd3P nanoparticle and PdP2 coated Pd3P core–shell nanostructures (Pd3P@PdP2). In Pd–P/SiO2-5, as shown in Fig. 4 , the lattice spacing at the NP exterior, 0.223 nm, and interior, 0.245 nm, confirm a two-phase morphology with a Pd3P core and PdP2 shell, in agreement with the results from EXAFS analysis. As a result, the ensemble size of Pd atoms on the surface of NPs decreased, evidenced by the fading away of the mode of bridge-bonded CO in DRIFT spectra, until fully isolated Pd atoms on the surface of nanoparticles were fabricated. 3.2 Dependence of PDH activity on P/Pd ratios The initial propane conversion and propylene selectivity of Pd–P/SiO2 catalysts are presented in Fig. 5 a, as a function of temperature. By contrast, the bare SiO2 and SiO2 supported phosphorus exhibited comparable and very low propane conversions of ∼1.5 % at 580 ℃ (Fig. S4). The data demonstrated a progressive increase in propane conversion for as-prepared catalysts as the test temperature increased, with the Pd–P/SiO2-1 catalyst displaying the maximum conversions in the range of 460–580 ℃, approaching >96 % of equilibrium conversion at 580 ℃. The propane conversion began to decline moderately with further addition of P/Pd ratios (35.8 % for Pd–P/SiO2-2 and 34.9 % for Pd–P/SiO2-5 at 580 ℃, respectively). With regard to the Pd/SiO2, the relatively low propylene selectivity undergoes a further decline with increasing test temperature. For instance, at a propane conversion of 34 %, the propylene selectivity was approximately 17 %, with methane and ethylene being the main by-products. This suggests that metal Pd is active for propane cracking and facilitated with increasing temperature. Despite propane cracking should yield equimolar amounts of methane and ethylene, the selectivity of methane over the Pd/SiO2 catalyst exceeded that of ethylene (product selectivity under different temperatures is shown in Fig. S5). This suggests the existence of a second pathway resulting in methane production, for example, cracking of higher hydrocarbons formed upon propylene oligomerization or deep-dehydrogenation of olefins [53,54], indicating the severe coke deposition on Pd nanoparticles. In comparison to the Pd/SiO2, the significantly enhanced selectivity was observed at any conversion level for phosphide catalysts. On the samples with a P/Pd ratio higher than 0.5, there are no obvious differences in propylene selectivity (97.5–98.6 %) between the Pd–P/SiO2-1, Pd–P/SiO2-2, and Pd–P/SiO2-5 catalysts, and it remained substantially unchanged with increasing dehydrogenation temperature. The enhanced propylene selectivity indicates that the side reactions and secondary pathway to form C1,2 products were inhibited by the formation of phosphide nanoparticles. Furthermore, our characterization results show that the Pdδ+ atoms were generated on the surface of phosphide nanoparticles, which is conductive to imparting a high propylene selectivity. The space time yields of propylene on these Pd-based phosphide nanoparticle catalysts are 65–78 mmolC3H6/gcat/h at 550 °C, and the value is much higher than PtP2 (34 mmolC3H6/gcat/h) and RuP (14 mmolC3H6/gcat/h) NP catalysts evaluated at 550 °C and 600 °C, respectively, which is comparable to that of the benchmark Pt-based alloy catalysts (>95 % propylene selectivity at near equilibrium conversion), as presented in Fig. 5d and Table S2. Rate measurements in the kinetics regime were performed to study the dehydrogenation behaviors of phosphide catalysts. The dehydrogenation rate (r) was normalized by the total amount of Pd site (determined by CO chemisorption and TEM analysis), which was expressed in terms of molsC3H8·molPd −1·s−1 to allow for fair comparison among different Pd sites with similar average particle sizes. For both metal Pd and phosphide NPs, the dehydrogenation rate increased gradually with an increase in the partial pressure of C3H8 (Fig. S6), and the dehydrogenation rates were proportional to the pressure of the C3H8 under low partial pressure of propane (< 20 kPa), suggesting a first-order dependence in C3H8. A first-order dependence in C3H8 is also corresponds with a reaction mechanism that is controlled by the cleavage of the C–H bond of propane [55]. The Pd–P/SiO2-1 catalyst demonstrated a significant enhancement in the value of dehydrogenation rate reaching a value of ∼0.46 mols·molPd −1·s−1 at 15 kPa C3H8 and 580 ℃, which is approximately 15 times higher than that of Pd/SiO2 (0.03 mols·molPd −1·s−1). To compare intrinsic dehydrogenation activity of Pd-P catalysts with different surface Pd atom configurations, the dehydrogenation rates were measured under different space times and extrapolated to zero space time, with the objective of elimination the impact of production inhibition and secondary reactions. Dehydrogenation rates extrapolated to zero space time on a per Pd site over phosphide nanoparticles with various P/Pd ratios are shown in Fig. 5b. At zero space time, the dehydrogenation rates of Pd–P/SiO2-1 were determined to be ∼0.455 mols·molPd −1·s−1, higher than Pd–P/SiO2-2 (0.326 mols·molPd −1·s−1) and Pd–P/SiO2-5 (0.308 mols·molPd −1·s−1), an increase of 1-order of magnitude in comparison to Pd/SiO2 (0.042 mols·molPd −1·s−1). The observed reactivity trends on Pd–P/SiO2 catalysts with different P/Pd ratios suggest that Pd3P NPs are more active than PdP2 NPs in PDH, while both of them exhibit satisfying propylene selectivity. The Arrhenius plots (ln(r) versus T−1) for the Pd- and Pd-phosphide nanoparticle catalysts are presented in Fig. 5c. For each catalyst, a high space velocity in the range of 200–300 mLC3H8·g−1·s−1 was selected in order to achieve a low propane conversion (<4.2 %), staying far away from equilibrium conversion under the test conditions, where the initial dehydrogenation rate can be obtained. The straight lines indicate that mass transfer limitations are negligible under test conditions. The steeper slope observed with the Pd nanoparticle catalyst corresponds to an Ea = 106.5 kJ/mol. By contrast, Pd-phosphide nanoparticle catalysts (P/Pd = 1, 2, 5) promote C–H bond activation with a decreased Ea (91.0, 92.1, and 92.6 kJ/mol for Pd–P/SiO2-1, Pd–P/SiO2-2, and Pd–P/SiO2-5 respectively), in line with the increased activity on Pd-phosphide catalysts, matching the trend of intrinsic activity among the phosphide catalysts. The crystal model of Pd3P as proposed by Rundqvist and Gullman [56] indicates that the Pd3P (0 1 0) surface exposes extended clusters of Pd atoms, comprising of three or four Pd atoms with an average Pd–Pd interatomic distance of 2.93 Å. By contrast, the PdP2 phase displays a separated or isolated Pd atoms, as evidenced by the monoclinic crystal structure of PdP2, as reported by Zachariasen [57]. This work provides evidence that Pd3P nanoparticle (Pd–P/SiO2-1) exhibits an abundance of contiguous Pd atoms on its surface, as indicated by the EXAFS fitting results (R Pd–Pd = 2.90 ∼ 2.93 Å) and the presence of a high ratio of bridge-bounded CO in the DRIFT spectra. These remarks led to the conclusion that the Pd3P with the clustered Pd atoms is more active than PdP2 with single-atom Pd sites, in line with the reported results of high dehydrogenation activity of Pt3M alloys and Pt clusters [58–60]. The experiments of C3H8 temperature-programmed surface reaction (C3H8-TPSR) analysis were conducted to investigate the interaction between C3H8 and catalytic sites. The onset temperature for C3H8 conversion and C3H6 production is nearly same (339 ℃) on the Pd-phosphide catalyst, suggesting that phosphide NPs directly convert C3H8 to C3H6 through a two-step C–H activation, without C–C activation related pathway occurring. Although comparable starting temperature for propane conversion was observed on Pd/SiO2 (Fig. 6 b), the temperature for C3H6 formation is higher than that of CH4 production (∼50 ℃). The strong adsorption of C3H6 on metal Pd or the higher onset temperature for C–H activation possibly explains this phenomenon. In conclusion, C3H6 is expected to desorb more easily from the Ptδ+ atoms, and the Pd-phosphide catalyst effectively restricts the excessive cracking of C3H6. Additionally, the interaction between hydrogen and the catalyst was investigated by EXAFS characterization, given that the selectivity towards propylene and the rate of coking are directly dependent on the interaction between active hydrogen species and the catalytic sites [21,23]. Fig. 7 compares the R space of the pre-reduced Pd/SiO2 catalyst treated in different atmospheres (H2 and He, respectively). It is clear that the central peak of the Pd–Pd bond shifts to a higher R value with H2-treatment, and a fit of the EXAFS spectrum gives a Pd–Pd CN of 10.2 at 2.78 Å, suggesting the lattice expansion caused by the formation of the PdHx phase [61]. In contrast, a weaker interaction between hydrogen and phosphide compounds, without PdHx species were detected on Pd-phosphide catalysts. Overall, serving as the catalytical sites to active the C–H bonds of propane rather than dissociate the C–C bonds, phosphide nanoparticle adsorbs propene and hydrogen in a favorable configuration, leading to desired adsorption features with respect to weaker strength in comparison with that on the Pd catalyst, therefore, the facile propylene desorption can be achieved on phosphide catalysts, which is responsible for its higher dehydrogenation selectivity. 3.3 Long-term stability and regeneration of Pd-phosphide catalysts The dehydrogenation stability of Pd-phosphide catalysts was evaluated at 550 ℃ with an undiluted propane stream. In Fig. 8 a, all the catalysts deactivated with time. As excepted, Pd/SiO2 catalyst deactivated relatively rapidly, with almost 95 % of the initial conversion lost during 1 h, giving a k d of 3.2 h−1 over a 6 h period. In contrast, the presence of P as a promoter clearly improves the dehydrogenation performance, and the deactivation rate is strongly dependent upon the P/Pd ratio. An initial propane conversion approaching equilibrium conversion accompanied by ∼98 % propylene selectivity was achieved over the Pd–P/SiO2 catalysts, however, which dropped monotonically for the first 0.5 h of the reaction and then proceeded to deactivate steadily. The Pd–P/SiO2-5 catalyst is more stable than other Pd-phosphide catalysts, giving a lower deactivation rate (0.15 h−1) compared to the Pd–P/SiO2-1 (0.28 h−1) and Pd–P/SiO2-2 (0.19 h−1). The STEM images verified the maintenance of the uniform particles in the spent Pd–P/SiO2-5 (∼2.6 nm), and only slight particle growth was observed in the Pd/SiO2 after the dehydrogenation test (∼4.2 nm), shown in Fig. S7. Coke formation on the catalyst after PDH test was studied by performing thermogravimetric analysis in flowing air (Fig. S8). The amount of coke present on the spent Pd–P/SiO2-5 catalyst was determined to be 3.2 % w/w, a value that is lower than that on the Pd–P/SiO2-2 (4.2 % w/w) and Pd–P/SiO2-1 catalyst (5.5 % w/w), as well as Pd/SiO2 (8.9 % w/w). For Pd-phosphide catalysts, the dehydrogenation rate correlates linearly with the amount of coke formation, leading to a trade-off relationship between activity and stability. Hydrogen was introduced in the reactor in addition to propane to slow down the coke deposition. The decline of deactivation rates on Pd-phosphide catalysts with co-feeding H2 (10 vol%) was observed in Fig. 8b. As the dehydrogenation product showed (Fig. S9), the reaction of cracking occurred to a negligible extent under the selected conditions. Meanwhile, the amounts of coke exhibited a notable decline (Fig. S8). It is commonly accepted that an increase in hydrogen pressure results in a reduction in the coverage of deeply dehydrogenated coke precursors on the metallic Pt, with a similar effect potentially occurring on Pd. Despite the implementation of rigorous test conditions to prevent catalyst deactivation, the loss of catalytic activity of Pd-phosphide is inevitable, which is also ubiquitous for Pt-based alloy catalysts. Gasification of coke by reaction with oxygen is frequently the most effective method for the removal of coke from used catalysts. In this work, the Pd–P/SiO2-5 catalyst was employed as a case to evaluate the efficacy of two coke elimination strategies: combustion with oxygen and washing with KOH-containing ethanol. The objective was to assess the feasibility of these approaches for the regeneration of the Pd-phosphide catalyst. Fig. 8b shows an overview of the dehydrogenation performance of the Pd–P/SiO2-5 catalyst during four successive dehydrogenation-regeneration cycles with two different regeneration methods. Using isothermal oxidation–reduction treatment (550 ℃), the gradual decline of initial dehydrogenation activity is observed after each regeneration process, and the decrease of propylene selectivity became more acute after 2–3 cycles. In contrast, the washing of the spent catalyst with KOH-ethanol at a mild temperature has been observed to be considerably effective. The Pd-phosphide catalyst presents high selectivity towards propylene (>98 %) and remains constant during four dehydrogenation-regeneration cycles. Despite the catalyst becoming deactivated over time, the initial dehydrogenation activity can be restored after each regeneration treatment. The TEM characterization of the spent and reactivated catalyst after each dehydrogenation/regeneration operation is illustrated in Fig. 9 . No discernible sintering or particle agglomeration was observed on the Pd-phosphide catalyst after the first dehydrogenation run (Fig. 9a). However, the catalytic gasification of coke in an oxidation environment leads to the severe particle growth, and the average size of Pd–P/SiO2-5 increased to 11.3 nm after three regeneration cycles, corresponding to 4.5 times larger than that of fresh catalyst (Fig. 9c, d). Despite the identical temperature being applied during both the dehydrogenation and regeneration processes, it is generally accepted that heat generated from the combustion of the hydrocarbon increases the temperature in the vicinity of the metal nanoparticles, providing sufficient thermal energy for metal atoms to migrate across the support surface, thereby facilitating sintering. As a result, the removal of coke is readily accomplished through gasification with oxygen, while sintering, on the other hand, is generally irreversible using this method. The removal of residual hydrocarbons from spent catalysts can be achieved through the washing of KOH-ethanol at moderate temperatures, with the process taking place relatively quickly. In the meanwhile, the TEM images of the Pd–P/SiO2-5 after each dehydrogenation/regeneration cycle showed retention of the particle size distribution. Furthermore, it is notable that the coke consumption process caused gradual loss of P on the Pd–P/SiO2-5 catalyst. ICP-MS analysis demonstrated a marked decrease in the P content during coke-burning process (Fig. 10 ), possibly phase separation can also occur, paralleling the deceased propylene selectivity and dehydrogenation stability. In a word, the recovery of the isolated Pdδ+ atoms sites through effective coke removal could enable catalysts to overcome the sintering of NPs and component fluctuations, making a stable dehydrogenation performance and prolonged lifetime of phosphide catalyst. 4 Conclusions This work provided analysis of well-defined Pd-phosphide nanoparticle catalysts for understanding the influence of the atomic configurations of active site, temperature, co-feeding of hydrogen, and regeneration methods on the activity and stability of the propane dehydrogenation. Both Pd3P and PdP2 surfaces are active and selective for C–H activation, achieving >98 % propylene selectivity at near equilibrium conversions. However, a trade-off relationship between activity and stability was demonstrated over Pd-phosphide catalysts. The site of clustered Pd atoms exhibited the highest dehydrogenation rate, also gave a higher deactivation rate. By contrast, the isolated Pdδ+ atom showed a more stable dehydrogenation performance. Additionally, an effective strategy for the rejuvenation of Pd-phosphide catalysts was developed based on its deactivation mechanism, leading to a long-term reaction/regeneration operation on the Pd-phosphide catalyst. Finally, while this study demonstrated the increased rate, selectivity and stability of Pd phosphide catalysts compared to Pd NP for propane dehydrogenation, metallic Pd is also catalytic for many other reactions. Thus, Pd phosphide catalysts may also display superior performance for those reactions as well. In addition, the low temperature regeneration procedure demonstrated here may also be applicable, especially for low temperature reactions. coredata.dc:description: A large number of alloy nanoparticle catalysts with novel configurations and compositions have been reported for efficient propane dehydrogenation. Although efforts have been made to rejuvenate the spent catalysts, the recovery of these well-defined active sites is still a daunting challenge. In this work, silica supported palladium-phosphide nanoparticles, with uniform particle sizes (∼2.5 nm) and specific crystal structures were prepared and systematically characterized. The combined structure analysis reveals that the exposed Pd site changes from metal Pd surface to few-atom Pd ensembles and fully isolated Pd atoms with gradually increasing P content. For identical reaction conditions of propane dehydrogenation, both the clustered Pd atoms and isolated Pdδ+ atoms exhibited dehydrogenation rates that is >10 times higher than the corresponding rate over Pd nanoparticle. Kinetic measurements demonstrated that the clustered Pd atoms on the surface of Pd3P nanoparticle shows the highest activity for C–H activation, while its also favored by coke deposition, leading to a trade-off relationship between activity and stability. By contrast, the Pd atoms on PdP2 surface exhibited a compromised dehydrogenation performance. Based on the deactivation mechanism of Pd-phosphide catalyst during dehydrogenation/regeneration cycles, an effective regeneration method, washing catalyst bed with alkaline-ethanol under mild conditions, was developed to remove deposited coke around dehydrogenation sites without sintering of nanoparticles. The structure–activity/stability relationship insights and facile regeneration method for the binary catalysts in this work offer improved knowledge of propane dehydrogenation catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: The structure dependency of the activity and stability of Pd-phosphide catalysts in propane dehydrogenation
